definition: (idiom) half true and half false
half/semi-/incomplete/(after a number) and a half
really/truly/indeed/real/true/genuine
half/semi-/incomplete/(after a number) and a half
fake/false/artificial/to borrow/if/suppose
see 假掰[gei1 bai1]
vacation

sentences.english: I gave my legs a couple of half-hearted blows and smiled winningly.
sentences.chinese: 我半真半假地打了幾下自己的腿，然後對他微微一笑。

sentences.english: What he told me was only half-truth.
sentences.chinese: 他告訴我的只是些半真半假的貨色罷了。
“無緣無故”只能說是半真半假。
這就是稱爲半真半假的言辭。

sentences.english: But my tangle of half-truths was all for naught.
sentences.chinese: 但我對半真半假糾紛是所有化爲烏有。

sentences.english: But as every woman knows, assurances like that are only half true.
sentences.chinese: 當然，每個女人都知道，這樣的保證歷來半真半假。

sentences.english: What he told me was only half-truth。
sentences.chinese: 他告訴我的只是些半真半假的東西而已。

sentences.english: Lies, evasions, and half truths. All are deceits.
sentences.chinese: 謊言，藉口，半真半假的陳詞，一切都是欺騙。

definition: to invent crazy nonsense/to cook up (excuses)/to talk at random/wild babble
lit. to add oil and vinegar/fig. adding details while telling a story (to make it more interesting)
see 煞有介事[sha4 you3 jie4 shi4]
to tell a lie
not to the point/wide of the mark/neither here nor there/irrelevant
to speak without thinking/to blurt sth out
to make a show of being very much in earnest (idiom)/to act as if one is taking things very seriously
deliberately mystifying/to make sth unnecessarily complicated
in deadly earnest/deadpan
a lie/untrue statement/misstatement
to add interest (to a story)/to sex up
lie
to make things up/to concoct (a story, an excuse etc)
to say sth without meaning it (idiom); to speak tongue in cheek/saying one thing but meaning sth different
to talk random nonsense (idiom); to say whatever comes into one's head
polite phrase/conventional greetings/cliché/to try to worm facts out of sb
